resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Welcome to Altera’s Nios II Software Tools and Design Flow Online Training My Name is Karl. In this training we will give a brief overview of what it takes to successfully create a Nios II processor based system. We’ll talk about all of the tools available as well as the design flow required.

Here’s the agenda for this presentation.
We will begin by examining an overview of Nios II based system development. Then moving on the software development flow along with the tools needed for that. And finally we’ll discuss all of the embedded software available for the processor as well as industry ecosystem support. Let’s begin with the overview.

Nios II Processor is Altera’s 2nd Generation 32-bit RISC Soft Microprocessor. It’s soft because it can be synthesized on to any Altera FPGA. It’s also very versatile coming in two variants fast optimize for speed and economy optimized for size. And can be used in almost any embedded system. It is a highly capable microcontroller class processor.

The Nios processor is highly configurable depending on your need some of the configurable options are listed here. You can dictate the cache size for both instruction and data cash.. you can open up tightly coupled memory ports, decide on arithmetic and interrupt controller implementation. You can add a MMU and MPU as necessary and there are many other options available.

Because the Nios II processor is softcore, you can also implement custom instruction and peripherals to help you accelerate and offload specific tasks.

Here’s entire system design flow for a Nios II processor based system.

The process starts at the top with the Qsys system integration tool which is part of the Quartus Prime software. In qsys, you would need to configure the options for the Nios II processor including custom instruction, you can select and instantiate peripheral and IP connected to the processor. After you’ve instantiate the various blocks, connect them to the Data or Instruction master of the Nios II processor and finally generate the Nios Qsys System. The result of the generate can be used by both the Quartus HW compile flow as well as the software development flow.

on the hardware side, Quartus Prime SW will compile the generated Qsys HDL and produce a FPGA hardware configuration file that needs to be either downloaded in to the FPGA or burned to flash. The qsys generate also create handoff files in order for the software build tools to create a custom Board support package. On the software development side, once the projects are created from the handoff files, you can add many custom or off the shelf drivers libraries and C source files. Add to this OSes or middleware as needed and you’ll be able to compile your SW project with the given GNU compiler. After an Executable Linkable File is created you would be able to debug this on chip.. In the debug phase, you will be able to fom the Nios software build tools, step, break, and run your software in a typical software development environment. Of course if you need to do hardware debug along with software debug all the usual Quartus FPGA based debugging tools such as SignalTap logic analyzer are available to you.

Once debug is done, program your flash with the FPGA image and the Software image and you will be able to ship your product.

At the center of software development and debug process is the Nios ii embedded design suite.. This is a complete tool from Altera which lets you perform all the usual software development tasks. With in the tool there’s the Software build tools which we’ll talk about in detail in the next section which allows you to compile and run you program.. The GUI version of the TOol is the Nios SBT for Eclipse. The tool can build automatically a board support package for your system including all the necessary device drivers and component support.. the Hardware Abstraction Layer or HAL API allows you to easily interact with components using an Unix like interface. In your software build tool you can also add many off the shelf embedded software such as Operating systems, network stacks, file systems, and other software. Once you’ve finished development the Software build tool allows you to easily debug over a JTAG connection which include breakpoint support, run control, and register and memory views.

Nios II EDS is the only tool you need for Nios II Software development and debug.
Now that we under stand the overview of Nios II System Development, let’s examine the software development flow including the necessary tools.

The only tool you need to develop software for the Nios II processor is the Nios II Embedded Design Suite or EDS.

It includes proprietary and open-source tools (such as the GNU C/C++ tool chain) for creating Nios II programs. At the center of the Nios II EDSthe Software Build Tools which contains commands, utilities, and scripts to hle pyou build applications board support packages and include software libraries. THe Nios II SBT for eclipse gives you plug ins to industry standard eclipse tool which makes developing and debugging software easy.

The Nios II EDS is available from altera.com free of charge and it is include as part of the Quartus download.

The main component in the Nios II EDS is the Software Build Tools. The SBTs automate board support package (or BSP) creation for Nios II processor-based systems, eliminating the need to spend time manually creating BSPs. The BSP provides a C/C++ runtime environment from Newlib, compiler from GNU, insulating you from the hardware in your embedded system. Altera BSPs contain the Altera hardware abstraction layer (HAL), an optional RTOS, and the device drivers to talk to the peripherals in your system.

There are two different flows that we can use to take advantage of these software build tools Command line and Eclipse based. Both allow you to create Nios II software projects, with detailed control over the software build process and both share the same utilities and TCL scripting capabilities.

The first flow is a eclipsed based GUI flow that runs the Nios II SBT utilities and scripts behind the scenes. You can accomplish all software development tasks within Eclipse, including creating, editing, building, running, debugging, and profiling programs. Some of the plug ins in the SBT for eclipse include a graphical BSP editor, quaruts Prime programmer, Nios Project templates and others .

Alteranatively, there is the Nios II SBT command line development flow, in which you create, modify, build, and run Nios II programs with Nios II SBT commands typed at a command line or embedded in a script. You run the Nios II SBT commands from the Nios II Command Shell.

Before talking about the software tools, it’s important to talk about the FPGA hardware tool and handoffs.
Nios II system hardware are required to be created in the Qsys integration tool where users can parameterize the Nios II processor and associated peripherals. Once complete, a Qsys generate will create the HDL files to be synthesized by the Quartus Prime Design Software and it will also produce the sopcinfo xml file which is used to relay important information about the system so the SOftware build tools can automatically build a Board Support Package for the Application Software.

Once the HW compile is done in Quartus Prime SW and the SOftware is compiled with the softwre Build tools, both can be downloaded on the board and you’ll be able to see the software running on the Nios II processor on the FPGA.

This slide shows the steps needed to create and debug a software application for the Nios II processor in the Software Build Tools.


First is to create a software project in the Software BUild Tools… Once the project is created you’ll be able to develop the software application which includes customizing the board support package.
Once software is created, configure the FPGA with the Quartus generated bitstream, remember FPGA needs to be configured before Nios can be executed. Once the FPGA is ready, the software build tools can be used to debug the software across JTAG giving the usual visibility into the CPU as well as the Control to the debug execution you would expect in any industry standard software debug tool. Lastly once the software and hardware are complete, program both to the On board flash.

Here’s the first step, creating a SW project.
In Eclipse, the easiest way to create a new application and BSP is to use a template. The project template dialog will ask you for the location of your sopcinfo file which is created when you generate your Qsys system.
This sopcinfo file is an XML based file that describes the Qsys system and is used to configure the software
The tool uses the information about your HW system to create a system library that targets your specific HW, known as the BSP.
Information about the HW such as memory components connected are used to create a linker script also part of the BSP. You can also customize the BSP with optimization settings, different software packages such as the interniche TCPIP stack or ROZIPFS, or specify which peripherals will be used for stdio or stderr.
Once you launched your first build, SBT will create the BSP system library for you. This will contain all of the options you’ve requested and it will also generate the system header file that will contain all of the macro definitions for the system parameters as #defines.

Once your project is created, you will be able to explore your created projects.. THere are two views in Eclipse, the Nios II view and the Debug view. THe NIos II view is the default view allowing you to explore the projects and source.
you create the project there will actually be two projects that you can see in the Project explorer Pane of the Eclipse software. These are the software application and the BSP.

A Nios II C/C++ application project consists of a collection of source and header files, along with an associated makefile. A typical characteristic of an application is that one of the source files contains function main(). An application can includes code that calls functions in other SW libraries and BSPs. The makefile compiles the source code and links it with a BSP and one or more optional libraries, to create an elf file.

A Nios II BSP project is a specialized library containing system-specific support code. This includes device drivers, os files, header files, HAL, and any packages you may have added to the system such as a network stack or file system. The BSP project source is automatically created by the Software Bulld Tools.

TO make the creating and the customization of the BSP project easier. THe Nios II SW Build Tools include the BSP Editor which can automatically generate various source files for the Nios BSP project.

In this tool, you’ll be able to easily edit, save, and generate sources for the BSP.

WIth in the BSP editor you’ll be able to select HAL feature options such as standard in/out components, timer components, enabling profiling and others.
You’ll also be able to create and set memory regions and assign to specific software sections which is used to generate the linker script.
For Qsys component that’s HAL compliant which is majority of Altera components including thing such as timers, DMAs, UARts and many others, device drivers will automatically pulled in to the BSP. In the BSP editor you’ll have the option to choose driver settings if those are available.
Lastly many software packages such as interniche’s niche stack can be enabled in the BSP Editor.
Once selections are made all you need to do is hit the generate button and the BSP project will automatically be updated with new relevant source files.

The Nios II EDS for Eclipse can be used easily and effectively to debug Nios applications across JTAG.

When you launch the application, the tool will automatically switch over to the nios II Debug perspective… which include many windows such as breakpoints, debug run control to make debugging easier.
The debugger graphic interface contains all of the usual features that you would expect from a modern debug tool. From the debug window in the upper left hand side you can see all of the basic controls and information displays. From here you can see which active debug sessions are running, for example you might be running simultaneous debugging of multiple processors. You can also control basic debug operations such as run, stop, step into , step over and so on.
In the window just below that one you can see the display of the source code that you are debugging. From here you can do all of the standard operations... Double click to add breakpoints and you can see the highlighted line of code indicating the position of the debugger.

Looking at other parts of the screen, you'll notice a range of other views that are available. For example you can see displays of variables, registers or memory locations. Each of these windows can be hidden or displayed as you require. The GUI is completely configurable in terms of what it displays and how it displays it.
At the top of the screen, you'll notice a series of icons. you can use these to configure your debug configurations as well as to launch a debug session which will download the SW code across JTAG and execute it on the Nios II Processor while allowing the debugger to see the state of the system.

Once you’ve finished debugging the software you’ll need to Flash the board.. There are many ways to do this depending on your device.

Nios II Flash Programmer can be used with any Flash component connected to the NIos II Processor.. THis eclipse plugin too will allow you to convert ELF and SOF files into a flash image that can be written in to flash by the Nios II Processor.

For certain scenarios, you can also use the mem_init_generate makefile target.. With this target, enabled in the SBT, you’ll be able to create memory initializing files for Max10 User Flash Memory, FPGA on chip ram, if you plan to boot from those memories. This target will also generate a data file for modelsim simulator if you choose to simulate your nios Ii system there.

Lastly when generating the flash image using either the flash programmer or mem_init_generate target, if the tool detects that you will be running the software in a different memory component from where it’s stored. Basically the .text and .entry sections are in different memory regions. Then the altera tool will automatically append a memcpy based boot copier at the front of your software image.

Here’s the summary of the entire NIos II SBT Flow.
We start with the Qsys system where hardware configuration are made.
ONce you generate the qsys system the sopcinfo containing hardware information is created and can be used to generate you BSP project when you create your project.
SBT for Eclipse will use the information stored in the sopcinfo file to create a system library or BSP that is used to support all of the custom hardware functionality that you configured into your system with Qsys. Using SBT, you can then add your application files and compile the system executable or elf file.

The HDL generated by Qsys is used by the Quartus prime software to generate the FPGA configuration file, or .sof file, this is then used by the quartus programmer to configure the FPGA device and download your Nios system into the hardware.

Once the HW is configured you can use the debugger to download, run and debug the application on the hardware

Lastly, you can use the softwre executable together with the FPGA configuration file to build a flash image which can then be downloaded into the flash on your board. This will enable your system to boot and run stand alone
In the last section of the class we’ll talk about the various embedded software packages available for the Nios II Processor as well as the support from industrywide ecosystem.

The first thing I’ll talk about is the Hardware Abstraction Layer that comes with the Software Build Tool.
The HAL offers a unix style API for interfacing to peripherals and systems services like timers and interrupts all hardware settings are abstracted using #define statements that have been automatically generated by the Softwre Build Tool nvironment. The Tools will also automatically update all hardware related software libraries, for example the newlib c library, as required by your hardware design. This means that you do not have spend any time changing your hardware interface code if the system design changes during the course of the project.

The HAL provides interrupt handling calls, timer and alarm facilities, device access calls, as well as system and device initialization calls. There are also ways to register custom functions on custom components so you can utilize C or Unix calls to access your component.

When you debug a Nios II based system. Some time you also need visibility into the Hardware.
With Nios systems, all Quaruts Prime Debugging tools are also available for use.

System Console is a great tool that lets you perform register and address level transactions through a Scriptable environment so you can see the state of your system and perform reads and writes to peripherals in your system without software.

The EMIF Toolkit lets you diagnose and debug calibration problems and produce margining reports for your external memory interface.

Transceiver Toolkit uses System Console technology to help FPGA and board designers validate transceiver link signal integrity real time in a system and improve board bring-up time.

Lastly for times where you need to see the signal and logic levels of internal FPGA logic, the SignalTapII Logic Analyzer is available for that purposes. All of these tools are shipped with the Quartus Prime Software.

in terms of peripherals, all Qsys components with an Avalon or AXI slave port can be used with the Nios II Processor, this include accelerators, interface protocols, memory controllers, DMA, Video IPs, DSP components, custom components and many others. With an FPGA fabric the limits are literally endless.

For most off the shelf Qsys components, Device drivers are also available, for altera components they are located at the Quartus install directory \ ip \ altera directory…
Most of these are automatically enabled in your Nios BSP project when the component is included in your qsys system.. You can however use the BSP editor to select driver options if they are available.

If you choose to use an operating system with your NIos II Processor, Here’s a list of current Operating SYstem support for Nios II Processor available..
Micro C OS II from Micrium is included with the software build tool however only the developer license is included, if you need to ship your product you’ll need to obtain a license from micrium.

This is a chart of middle ware and graphics libraries available from various vendors.
Of note is that the Read-only zip file system from Altera and the NicHESTack TCP/IP network stack nios II edition is included in the nios II SBT and can be enabled from the BSP.
For all other software packages contact the vendors directly.

Lastly, here’s a table of additional third party software development tools available for the Nios II processor incase the default ALtera’s SBT does not meet your needs.
Windriver Workbench can be used for software running on embedded linux.
Mentor offers GNU toolchain support for embedded Linux on the Nios II Processor.
Altium, MIPS technologies, and the open source community all have tool chains available as well for various environments.

This concludes this overview training.
If you would like more information on the Nios II Processor the best place is the Nios II Documentation page on altera.com there you will find various user guides available on the processor, IPs, and software. THere’s also a one-click download that include all available documentation. INclude in that set is the very useful Nios II Hardware and SOftware developer’s handbooks.
The nios II EDS SUpport page is a great place to visit for the latest information on the Nios embedded design suite.
FOr user generated documentation and discussions visit the Altera Forum and Altera Wiki where there are much information about Nios II and associated boards.
THe Nios II Landing page on altera.com is a great portal to all your Nios Needs. and finally the eclipse help content and welcome page contain much information about the Software build tools for eclipse.

Here are the follow-on free online trainings that may interest you.

We have an short online training on how to use the nios II software build tool as well as the features available in the Nios II Hardware Abstraction layer.

If you’ll be using the Nios II Processor with the Max 10 FPGA then we have a special training on how to utilize the on board flash in the MAX 10 devices in a NIos II System and how to boot from that flash.

If you would like more information on the hardware side, see the Nios Hardware Development as well as the custom components and instructions training.

I hope you’ve enjoyed this training.
One last thing: when you registered for this on-line training, you should have received a link to a short survey where you can provide feedback. We’d greatly appreciate it if you’d fill out that survey now. We’re constantly updating and improving our training materials, and your feedback helps us create the materials that you want! Thank you for your feedback.
Thank you very much again for attending the Nios II SW Tools and Design Flow online training. My name is karl. Best of luck with all of your designs.
